newsitem.title: USA: Key senator sees 50-50 odds for power bill in 1998.
newsitem.headline: Key senator sees 50-50 odds for power bill in 1998.

text.p: Sen. Dale Bumpers, the sponsor of sweeping legislation to break up electric utility monopolies, Tuesday laid 50-50 odds on Congress passing a bill by October 1998 to open U.S. power markets to competition.
He told reporters, "No," when asked whether a bill would pass this year, and said "50-50" when asked about the chances for a bill passing before the 105th Congress ends next year.
He also predicted that electricity legislation would not include provisions to break up local natural gas utility monopolies, a move being pushed by natural gas producers.
"Electric restructuring is a load right now without even thinking about gas company unbundling," Bumpers said at a natural gas industry luncheon. "It'd be far too complex to add it into the debate."
He repeated that the House would have to pass an electric restructuring bill to spur action in the Senate.
While House Commerce Committee chairman Rep. Thomas Bliley aims to get a power markets bill out of his committee this year, Bumpers said that was no guarantee that the House would vote on it.
"Getting it out of committee and getting a vote on the floor are two different things," he said.
